p: Third, increased expression of α-synuclein has been observed in iPSC-derived neurons from PD patients with mutations in α-synuclein [ 54, 55], LRRK2 [ 73, 75], parkin [ 93, 99], PINK1 [ 93] or DJ-1 [ 114]. The significant role of α-synuclein in PD has been well documented [ 152]. Debates on whether α-synuclein is transmitted between neurons and whether such transmission causes the selective degeneration of nigral DA neurons in PD [ 153, 154] make it very important to generate patient-specific midbrain DA neurons to address these issues. It remains unclear how α-synuclein accumulation causes the selective loss of nigral DA neurons. One possibility is that α-synuclein increases cytosolic dopamine concentration more significantly in nigral DA neurons than in VTA DA neurons [ 155]. Dopamine-induced oxidative stress, in conjunction with mitochondrial oxidative stress downstream of α-synuclein overexpression, may impact nigral DA neurons much more than other types of cells [ 156].
